Award.AbstractNarration:
The Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI) is a suite of research infrastructure rapidly taking shape in prototype form across the United States. GENI aims to transform experimental research in networking and distributed systems, as well as emerging research into very large socio-technical systems, by providing a suite of infrastructure for at-scale experiments in future internets. Nationwide experiments began in summer 2010, and GENI now supports a wide range of interesting research experiments across the nationwide meso-scale GENI prototype, built from GENI-enabled commercial equipment, that spans 14 US campuses and the two national research backbones (Internet2, National Lambda Rail [NLR]). Research teams presented 9 major demonstrations of live, nationwide experiments at the 9th GENI Engineering Conference in November 2010. About 20 research experiments are now starting to drive GENI?s evolving design.

This project will fund the third round of development and prototyping for GENI, effectively completing the transition from building GENI to using GENI for at-scale research. This effort includes 1) enhancing the meso-scale build-out to include six major regional research networks across sixteen states, connecting campuses to Internet2 an NLR; 2) increasing the campus WiMAX deployments via multi-cell sites, android handsets and vehicular experiments; 3) creating, deploying and operating ~54 GENI racks within campuses, regional networks and national backbones; 4) deploying and operating two robust, complementary instrumentation and measurement systems; and 5) expanding the GENI experimenter community by creating educational materials, running workshops and summer schools and starting ongoing operations and helpdesk support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Note: GENI is supported by multiple NSF awards. This outcomes report summarizes overall GENI-related outcomes. The specific work of this award, “Solicitation 3 Design and Prototyping,” addresses the nationwide deployment of GENI infrastructure and supporting capability development.

GENI's Goals

The Global Environment for Network Innovations - GENI - is a suite of research infrastructure that comprises a distributed laboratory deployed across the United States. (See Figure 1.) GENI aims to transform experimental research in networking and distributed systems by providing a suite of infrastructure for "at-scale" experiments in future internets.

GENI supports a wide variety of experiments, including the following:

  • Experiments ranging from small to “at-scale” experiments.
  • Both experiments that are compatible and experiments that are incompatible with today’s Internet.
  • Not only controlled, repeatable experiments, which which will greatly help improve our scientific understanding of complex, large-scale networks, but also trials of experimental services that ride atop or connect to today’s Internet and that engage large numbers of users.
  • A variety of classroom and research experiments.

Although GENI’s goal is to support “at-scale” experiments on future internets, our plan has never been to build a separate, parallel set of infrastructure “as big as the Internet,” which is clearly infeasible. Instead, the approach has been to “GENI-enable” existing testbeds, campuses, regional and backbone networks, cloud computation services, and commercial equipment to be programmable, virtualized and sliceable, so that they can support end-to-end experiments. 

GENI's Results

GENI has addressed its initial purpose of supporting innovative research, and it has gone beyond these goals in a number of ways. The GENI project office and the GENI community have built GENI with an initial at-scale deployment now in place. GENI’s use in the classroom is lowering the barrier for laboratory-based learning in computer science education. It is increasingly finding application in data- and compute-intensive domain sciences. Furthermore, GENI infrastructure is supporting advanced application development in areas of societal impact, through initiatives such as US Ignite. (See Figures 2 and 3.)

GENI continues to see explosive growth in usage for both research and education – over 10,000 unique users have turned to GENI, allocating over a quarter million GENI configurations. (See Figure 4.) GENI’s user base reaches more than 180 US universities and over 30 countries. (See Figure 5.)

Under this award, the GENI community designed and deployed GENI nationwide, incorporating sixty GENI racks and twenty-four GENI wireless base stations at universities, regional and backbone networks, and partner institutions across the US. GENI hardware and concepts are increasingly extending beyond GENI proper and being integrated with campus scientific computing infrastructure. More researchers from the GENI community are publishing their results – the bibliography of GENI-relevant publications now includes over three hundred entries.

Educators continue to develop GENI-based curriculum and employ GENI in their classrooms. Over 55 different instructors now regularly use GENI in their classes. This academic year (2016-2017), instructors are using GENI in at least 47 different courses with total enrollment of over 1400 students.

Future Directions

The GENI community and GENI technology are playing a vital role in leading the development of research cyberinfrastructure. Key GENI concepts are increasingly embedded into new projects, such as the NSF Future Cloud research platform. Similarly, the central GENI notions of slicability and deep programmability are finding their way into future internet and distributed cloud research testbeds worldwide. (See Figure 6.) The NSF CISE "Looking Beyond the Internet" Steering Group Report identifies GENI as a thought leader for future research infrastructure, and the new Tomorrow’s Internet Project Office (TIPOFF) effort is poised to build upon GENI’s success. 

As GENI is being created and improved, it is engaging an unusually wide range of participants from a cross-section of US institutions. This community is designing and developing GENI technology, deploying GENI on their campuses, and using GENI in their research. Many universities are applying GENI in their courses, with the potential to transform totally how experimental computer science is taught and learned.

Perhaps most important to us, the GENI community, is that the newest generation of networking and distributed systems researchers have enthusiastically taken up research leadership roles in an ambitious project of national importance. We would like to congratulate the numerous academic and industrial groups – both Principal Investigators and many graduate students – who play a role in defining and shaping GENI.

Mark Berman, GENI Project Director
